person.note: Jewishness suggested based on name but this is a very unusual biblical name, see Introduction 6.6.3. CPJ1, p. 200, suggested that it was a misspelling of ̓Αβιῆτος, see under Abitai (S-H/M), in which case there is also little reason to consider it Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.2.
This reading is suggested by the editor. This is one of the variant readings of LXX (to 1 Sam 8:2, see H & R Suppl. 2), see Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.
So in LXX (to 1 Sam 22:20), see H & R Suppl. 3, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Described in the text as one of several Jews who had διάλεξις γέγονεν (conducted a dispute) with Christians, in the days of Pope Silvester.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
These are Pope Silvester’s dates, see above, n. 3.

In the Vulgate the form of this name is ‘Abner.’ Nevertheless, the editors of the inscription identified this name as אבנר, but see Josephus, AJ20:23, where the name ̓Αβεννήριγος is used for the king of the city of Charax Spasini on the mouths of the Tigris and Euphrates in Mesopotamia.
Considered Jewish because of the name, but the biblical name Abner was not used by Jews, see Introduction 6.6.3.
The inscription is from Pompeii. This is the date of its destruction.
This is Abraham’s name before it was changed, see e.g. Gen 11:21.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
So in Josephus (e.g. BJ4:531), see Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness indicated by name, but see above, n. 1.
It seems that the scribe has reversed the letters μ and ι, see Introduction 2.8.3. On the additional ι see below, n. 23.
Jewishness indicated by name, see above, n. 1.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
See above, n. 4. On this case ending see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
So in LXX for אברם, see H & R Suppl. 4, and Introduction 2.2.1.

In LXX the form of the name אברהם is transliterated as ̓Αβραάμ, see H & R Suppl. 4. The name is declined according to Greek grammar, see Introduction 2.2.1.1.1. On the additional ι see Introduction 2.2.1.1.2.
Described in the text as ̔Εβρείῳ (Hebrew), see Introduction 6.1.2
Apparently mentioned in a list of bricklayers.
And see also loc. cit.pl. xxiv.

The list was found in association with the remains of apparently the Jewish Onias Temple in Leontopolis, see Petrie’s discussion in his Hyksos and Israelite Cities, 26. The assumption that he is Jewish is supported by three factors: 1. The location of the find; 2. His biblical name (but see above, n. 1); 3. The name is followed by the Demotic ethnicon sign, indicating a foreigner.
See above, n. 8. Also another Jew is mentioned in the papyrus (Yohanan [17] son of Joseph [44]).
So in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 4, and Introduction 2.2.1.

The editor wrote that the names on this papyri “all … appear to be Jewish,” but since we are dealing with the sixth century, they could of course also all be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7. The papyrus is signed with a cross.

Some persons in this papyrus have biblical names, which suggested to the editor that “The whole nomenclature betrays persons of Jewish extraction,” but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7. The Coptic subscription particularly suggests this.
Described in the text as Σαμαρίτ, see Introduction 6.1.6.4.
The papyrus is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
On this form see above, n. 4. On the additional vowel before the case ending see Introduction 2.2.1.1.2. On the interchange of ι and η see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3
See above, n. 33. On the double β see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
In Greek – ἀπὸ <σ>υν<αγωγῆ>ς[̓Αγ]ριπνιαδς. The reading is from JIWE 2, 562. In CIJthis part of the inscription is not transcribed.
Jewishness of this inscription is indicated by a mention of a synagogue, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.4.
The inscription is accompanied by a verse in Jewish characters with the word ישורון. On this word being Samaritan see Introduction 6.1.6.4.
Pherbitis is a location in Egypt.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
The inscription mentions Hades, see Introduction 6.6.5 and 6.10.2.
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, see above, n. 1. However, the inscription is a pagan dedicatory inscription to the God Pan, see Introduction 6.6.5 and 6.10.2.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.3.

IJO 1, 329 considered Hebrew inscriptions from the region as medieval, although he wrote “It is impossible to date Hebrew writings in an area where there are so few examples, and none with any internal dating.” One may assume he considered them all medieval based on the transitional pattern in all Europe, where, in the Middle Ages, Jews preferred to use Hebrew rather than the local scripts in their inscriptions, see Introduction 6.2.3.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.
Because it is probably the Semitic name intended here (see above, n. 1), there is no standard Greek transliteration for it, nor for its vocalization.

The inscription comes from the western cemetery of Apollonia, and may have been described by Robinson, AJA 17 (1913) 185, as follows: “In regard to the date of these inscriptions from the tombs west of Apollonia, it should be noted that in several cases the seven-branched candlestick is roughly incised at the side of the entrance,” see Introduction 6.3.1. However, he may refer to other tombs, see Introduction 6.5.5. CJZC also mentions this name as a sign of Jewishness but see Introduction 6.6.1, and n. 1 above.
Josephus transliterates this name as ̓Αψάλωμος, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.2.7, p. 19. This is obviously a variation on the same form, where α replaces ω, see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.

The name is most likely Jewish, although see Introduction 6.6.1, and above, n. 1. The inscription is probably a (pagan) temple dedicatory inscription. On Jews in such finds see Introduction 6.6.5 and 6.10.2.
So is his name recorded in the Vulgate, see Introduction 2.2.2.

Jewishness suggested based on the biblical name and the location, next to a man named Moses (18), but the editor concedes he could also be Christian, and see Introduction 6.6.7. The name of Agag, the king of the despised Amalekites, was never used by Jews, see Introduction 6.6 3.
So in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 1, and Introduction 2.2.1.

Jewishness suggested by an earlier editor, based on reading of the name thus (instead of Λάρων as read by the first publisher). It was, however, rejected by CPJ on the basis that the name was not used by Jews in Egypt, see above, n. 1.
This form of the name is not recorded, but the loss of one α can be imagined, see Introduction 2.8.2.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
In this case it could mean “his brother,” see above, n. 1.
Since this person is Jewish (see below, n. 3), it was assumed that this is a transliteration of this biblical name, but in LXX it is transliterated ̓Ιωβ, see H & R Suppl. 92.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.
Josephus records this biblical name as ̔́Ηλων (AJ 1:265), see Introduction 2.2.1.
The editor thought this was a biblical name, and thus considered the inscription Jewish, but this is doubtful, see Introduction 6.6.3.
The editor dated the inscription to the “Kaiserzeit.”
See Introduction 2.1. The form ̓Ελίαβος is recorded in Josephus (AJ 6:161), see Introduction 2.2.1.

The biblical name is hardly an indication of Jewishness, see Introduction 6.6.3.However, the inscription comes from Palestine (though not from a regular Jewish cemetery, from a very Jewish town) see Introduction 6.5.7.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
So Josephus records the name of this prophet, (e.g. AJ 8:329), see Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness suggested by Clarysse, “Jews in Trikomia,” 194, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
In this papyrus he writes a declaration instead of a Jew, because the latter is illiterate. As he needs to be trusted, he may be Jewish himself, but need not be, see Introduction 6.1.4.1.

Both forms represent the name of a synagogue in Rome. It could be designated after the prophet Elijah, although his name is nowhere transliterated so. If the synagogue was named after a person, Elijah was probably intended.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.

This is the name of the synagogue. It could refer to a member of the community, who founded the building, and it could refer to the biblical prophet of this name, see above, n. 7. For other suggestions see Leon, Jews of Rome, 145-7.

Jewishness inscription decided by its similarity to other clearly Jewish inscriptions from Taranto found close by (e.g. CIJ 629), and the use of Greek makes for the early date, see Introduction 6.5.8. However, these are no direct Jewish indicators and the name Elijah was rare among Jews, see above, n. 1.
JIGRE interpreted this name as theophoric, obviously referring to the אלי element in the name. If so, they assumed it is אליה.
See Introduction 2.1. The reconstruction is according to Hachlili, see IJO 1, p. 47.
This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.4.1.1.1.
For the loss of the א at the head of the name see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.5, p. 29.
The Hebrew transcription in this publication is so bad, one should consult the initial publication in Cross, Leaves, 151.
This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.4.1.1.1, and it is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
In Pseudo-Philo 4:2 the name of this prophet is recorded as ‘Elisa.’

The Inscription was considered Jewish because it contains a symbol that resembles the menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.1, but another symbol is understood by CIJas an idiosyncratic chi-rho and it views it as a Christian inscription. It also contains the pagan formula D(is) M(anibus) (to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

This is the way the name of this person is spelt both in Josephus and in Aristand 1 Macc. This is also Josephus’ orthography for the biblical figure with this name (Schalit, NB, 42), see Introduction 2.2.1.
In Greek – τῶν ἀπὸ τῆς χώρας ἵερων (of the priests of the land).
Jewishness indicated by 1. name, see Introduction 6.6; and 2. role in the text as defender of Judaism.
This is the date of the Battle of Raphia, in conjunction with which the name is mentioned.

On this longer version and other such names see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.1, p. 29. The names אלעזר and אליעזר were distinct one from the other both in the Hebrew Bible (אלעזר – Aaron’s son, Exod 6:23; אליעזר – Abraham’s slave, Gen 15:2) and in rabbinic literature. But this distinction does not seem to have carried that much weight in our documentation system, see vol. 1, p. 71, n. 8.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
The form Λάζαρος or Λάζαρ (לעזר ליעזר;) is a colloquial form of ̓Ελεάζαρος (אליעזר; אלעזר), see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.2, p. 29.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.5.
This short form of the name is also recorded in Palestine, see under Eleazar (125; 127) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 69.
The first version is from col. 3, l. 70, the second from col. 5, l. 122. See also Introduction 2.1, and previous note.
The papyrus is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
Find loction was sealed in the days of Septimius Severus, and this is his date of death.
In Greek – Μασαραίου (from the Hebrew מצרים).

The ostracon was found in Masada, in Palestine, together with the other documents of the Jewish defenders of the site in the war of 66-73 against Rome, see Introduction 6.8. The person also has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.6.
See vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1, pp. 48-9. This person is recorded under Eleazar (174) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 70.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
The inscription is bilingual. For both these forms see above, n. 11.
Found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.5.7. The name is also inscribed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This orthography of the name is also recorded in Palestine, see under Eleazar (89; 134) (B/M) in vol. 1, pp. 67 and 69.
Jewishness is indicated by the name, see Introduction 6.6, and by the Hebrew in which the inscription is written, see Introduction 6.2.2.
Jewishness suggested based on name, see Introduction 6.6. The name, however, is reconstructed and the temple on which this inscription was found is pagan, see Introduction 6.10.2.
Perhaps to be identified with the previous.

state.note: Epheboi inscription, Cyrene, Oliverio & Pugliese Carratelli

person.note: See above, 44. Obviously the additional σ is a scribal error, see 2.8.1.
This person could be Jewish, because of his name, see Introduction 6.6, but this is a pagan epheboi list, see Introduction 6.6.5.

state.note: Epheboi inscription, Cyrene, Oliverio & Pugliese Carratelli
Epheboi inscription, Cyrene, Oliverio & Pugliese Carratelli

person.note: A Nomophylacos was a civil post. Jewishness is indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
This would be an abbreviated form of this biblical name. It is recorded in biblical period ostraca, see Zadoq, Pre-Hellenistic Israelite Anthroponomy, 279 (72127), 282 (721213).
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.3.

IJO 1, 329, considered Hebrew inscriptions from the region as medieval, although he wrote “It is impossible to date Hebrew writings in an area where there are so few examples, and none with any internal dating.” One may assume he considered them all medieval based on the transitional pattern in all Europe, where in the Middle Ages Jews preferred to use Hebrew rather than the local scripts in their inscriptions.

This name is recorded as Asaph in the Vulgate. In the translation into Latin of the apocryphal 3 Ezra 1:15 the name is transliterated as Asaphat, see Introduction 2.2.2. On the declension see Introduction 2.2.2.1.
Described in the text as “Asphatii Judeus” (Asaf the Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.5.
This inscription is reported to have been first read in the 15th Century. CIJ I, pp. 527-32, concludes that it is a 15th century forgery.
In LXX this name is recorded both as Βηβαί and as Βηβεί, see H & R Suppl. 39. This could be another variation on this form.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to persons with biblical names mentioned in the same document, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
As such this name is not recorded, but LXX has Βανίας and Βανναιοῦς for this name (see H & R Suppl. 35), and it is nearer to this form than any other known name.
Mentioned in a list which includes many biblical names, but is of a late date and could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.

So he is designated in the Erfurt Ms. but the preferable Vienna Ms. and the Sifre Deut (253) has בנימין, which makes more sense. מנימין is the biblical name of one of the twenty four priestly families mentioned in 1 Chr 24 (9, and more specifically Neh 12:17). In LXX the biblical מנימין is transliterated as Βενιαμείν (H & R Suppl. 38). Kosowski, ad loc., however suggests that the name derive from the Greek μνήμω (I remember), and see under Greek names.
Mentioned in rabbinic literature, see Introduction 6.7. Described in the tradition as גר מצרי (Egyptian proselyte), see Introduction 6.1.6.2.
See vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1, pp. 48-9. This person is recorded under Benjamin (4) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 82, but not included in the statistics.
The papyrus is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
So in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 38, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
See below, n. 12. There is obviously vowel confusion here between ε, ι and η, see Introduction 2.8.3.

Jewishness indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1. Interestingly, the inscription also includes the formula Εἱς Θε(ός) (God is one). On the extent of its Jewishness see Di-Segni, SCI 13 (1994), and Introduction 6.10.1.
This suffix is found neither in LXX nor in Josephus, but the latter records a similar suffix – Βενιαμίς, see Schalit, Namenbuch, 26.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but he could also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
This is Lifshitz’s reading. Robert read Βενιδάης. Schwabe, BIES 14 (1949) 110, suggested בן אדא. On the reading suggested here see above, n. 12.
Jewishness is indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
This form is recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 38, and Introduction 2.2.1.
His grandson, Τανοῦμ, buried in Jaffa, is no longer considered of Egyptian origin, and will be recorded in vol. 2 under Tanhum (S-H/M).
Found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.5.7.
According to the editor Parembole is a village in Egypt.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 36, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness of inscription indicated by the Hebrew – שלום, see Introduction 6.2.
The editor identified the inscription as “Late Roman.”
This is a synagogue inscription from Palestine, see Introduction 6.8. It is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
The amulet is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.

The reading is according to W. Horbury, “A Personal Name in a Jar-Inscription in Jewish Characters from Alexandria,” Vetus Testamentum44 (1994) 104. This is a very Hellenized form because of the case-ending. It is doubtful whether the scribe knew this was an original Hebrew name.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 36, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness of inscription indicated by the Hebrew – שלום, see Introduction 6.2.
The editor identified the inscription as “Late Roman.”
This seems to be the same name, where the α has fallen. For the form Βαραχίας see Josephus, AJ 9:250.
Jewishness indicated by name, but see Introduction 6.6.1.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 47, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Described in the text as one of several Jews who had διάλεξις γέγονεν (conducted a dispute) with Christians, in the days of Pope Silvester.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
These are Pope Silvester’s dates, see above , n. 3.
This name is transliterated in LXX as Γερά, see H & R Suppl. 46, and also Introduction 2.2.1.1.1.
His inscription mentions ὕμνοις ̔Εβρέων (Hymns of the Hebrews), see Introduction 6.1.2.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 52, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Described in the text as one of several Jews who had διάλεξις γέγονεν (conducted a dispute) with Christians, in the days of Pope Silvester.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
These are Pope Silvester’s dates, see above, n. 3.
So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 50, and Introduction 2.2.1.
It has been suggested by Fikhman, SCI 15 (1996) 226, that this papyrus is associated with Jews. I assume he means those with biblical names. However, see Introduction 6.6.7.
This variant reading of the name is already found in the Bible, see e.g. 1 Kgs 3:14.
Jewishness decided by the Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.3.
A star of David on the inscription makes it late, and see also Introduction 6.5.8.

The reading is according to JIWE 1, 118. CIJ read Λαυδάτου. It makes sense that the name intended is a variation on David, even though this form is unknown, since the name was found elsewhere in the Jewish cemetery of Taranto, see previous person. On this sort of declension see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 22-3.
Jewishness of the inscription is decided by the bilingual (Hebrew and Greek) characters, see Introduction 6.2.3. It is dated early because of the Greek, see Introduction 6.5.8.
So is his name recorded in the Vulgate, see Introduction 2.2.2.
This may be a reference to the biblical David, but other graffiti on the wall mention real people, e.g. Albinus. If he is a person, he is probably Jewish, because of the name, see Introduction 6.6.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
Although this transliteration is nowhere recorded, it seems to fit this name, which is also found (in Jewish characters) in Edfu.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.1.
So in Nachtergael, MA 27 (1994) 45-6. This is how this name is transliterated in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 49.
So in CPJ284. For the double λ see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
Jewishness indicated by name, and name of father, see Introduction 6.6.
So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 50, and Introduction 2.2.1.
In Greek – ἐν τῇ α̓τῇ μητροπόλει Κωνσταντίᾳ … φαρμακείας ποιήσας (in that metropolis Constantia … he performed magic).
Described in the text as τις ̓Ιουδαῖος (a certain Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
So according to J. Starr, “Byzantine Jewry on the Eve of the Arab Conquest (565-638),” JPOS 15 (1935) 285, n. 24.
The vast majority of persons in this family have biblical names, which may suggest a Jewish family, but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
See below n. 12, and for the extra ι, see Introduction 2.2.1.1.2.

Some persons in this papyrus have biblical names, which suggested to the editor that “The whole nomenclature betrays persons of Jewish extraction,” but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7. The Coptic subscription particularly suggests this.
The form Δανίηλος is recorded in Josephus (e.g. AJ 10:188), see Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness suggested because of location (found in a synagogue, but see next note).
The inscription was found in a modern synagogue. For similar problems see Introduction 6.5.8. The editors of IJO 1, App2, think it should be dated to a late medieval synagogue.
Perhaps a reference to the biblical Daniel.

As such this form is not recorded anywhere, as it obviously completely ignores the gutturals. For the form אושעיה in Elephantine, Egypt, in the Persian period see Zadok, Pre-Hellenistic Israelite Anthroponomy, 288 (721220), 292 (72136).
The papyrus was composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.

Josephus does not record this name. In LXX it is transliterated ̔Ελλήλ (H & R Suppl. 59).̔Ελλήλος would be the declined Greek form of the name, see Introduction 2.2.1. On the pronunciation of this name, see Kutscher, Hebrew and Aramaic, 84-5.
His name was found in a list of Jews preserved with personal documents of the refugees of the Bar Kokhba Revolt, see 6.8.
In Greek – Κυρηναῖ[ος]. This person is recorded under Hillel (7) (B/M) in vol.1 , p. 88, but not included in the statistics.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
In LXX this name is transliterated as Ζαβδιήλ/Ζαβδειήλ, but this is a variation. On the double β, see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3. The loss of the ι is obviously a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.2.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This name is recorded in the LXX apocrypha, as Ζαβδαῖος, see H & R Suppl. 64. On the interchange of ζ and σ see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
Jewishness suggested based on the name, but there is no indication that this name was specifically Jewish, see above, n. 1.
Because it is probably the Semitic name intended here (see above, n. 1), there is no standard Greek or Latin transliteration for it, nor is its vocalization. This is a Latin variant.
This is a list of Roman soldiers.
Jewishness suggested based on the Semitic names of the soldiers in this list, but they need not be Jews, see above, n. 1.
CPJ did not include this papyrus. Fikhman, “CPJ IV” 294, n. 14, suggests he may be Jewish, based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.1, and above, n. 1.
1. The inscription was not found in but near the Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.1; and 2. the name is Semitic, but see Introduction 6.6.1, and above, n. 1.

The inscription, containing the names of three freedmen, was considered Jewish because of the names – Baricha, Zabda and Achiba – but all three, although Semitic, need not be understood as Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.1.
The form Ζάβδος is also recorded in the LXX apocrypha for this name, see H & R Suppl. 64.
See above, n. 11. This is a Greek variant.

Because it is probably the Semitic name intended here (see above, n. 1), there is no standard Greek transliteration for it. This Semitic form was used as a nickname for one of the last Seleucid Kings, see WGE, 436.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
On this as a variation of the name זכריה see under Zachariah (5) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 90 and p. 91, n. 15.
Described in the text as τῶν ̓Ιουδαίων (from among the Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
His disputant is Athanasius the bishop of Alexandria.
These are the years of Athanasius’ office as bishop of Alexandria, see previous note.
This is the Hebrew form of the previous name, see above, n. 2.
1. Appears in rabbinic literature, see Introduction 6.7; and 2. bears the title “rabbi,” see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4.
This is an unusual transliteration of the previous, see above, n. 2, but this name is clearly intended.
His children paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
So in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 66, and Introduction 2.2.1.
The inscription was considered Jewish because believed to be a synagogue inscription, based of the name – Zacharias, but it could of course also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.

See Introduction 2.1. This is an unusual vocalization of both the expected Bar and Zacharias. Perhaps it is an Egyptian dialect, and see also under Samuel (B/M), nos. 25-6. For the Bar prefix see Introduction 2.2.1.1.5. Also for this name see Williams, JSJ 38 (2007) 317, n. 56.
The inscription was acquired in Alexandria, but its provenance is unknown.
This is a dedicatory inscription. It was identified as a synagogue dedication, and thus Jewish. Jewishness is based on the name Samuel in the inscription, but see Introduction 6.6.7.
The editor compared the inscription to CIJ 964 (from Ashkelon), dated to 604 CE.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
See below, n. 10. For this sort of declension see Introduction 2.2.1.1.7.
Jewishness suggested based on name (and other biblical names in the list), but see Introduction 6.6.3.
The papyrus is dated to one of these years.
The name ̓Αγγαῖοςis recorded in LXX for e.g. Neh 5:1 (H & R Suppl. 5) , see Introduction 2.2.1.
Based on the name, Fikhman, “CPJ IV,” 294, n. 18 is sure he is Jewish, but see Introduction 6.6.3.

state.note: Epitaph on lead sheet, Santa Maria, Millás

person.note: Jewishness indicated by Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.1.
The inscription may date to the Persian period.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly non-Jewish names, and thus I consider them all non-Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
This name is transliterated in LXX as ̔Ηζείρ or ̔Ιεζείρ or Χηζείν, see H & R Suppl. 67, 78, 160, but not like here. On the other hand, WGE, 1659, records the name of a northern people as Χάζαροι.

This name was found in a list of Semitic, but probably not Jewish names. CPJ thought this was the biblical חזיר but even in that document the name is that of a family and not that of a person, and see Introduction 6.6.3, and above, n. 2. Because חזיר means pig, it is unlikely that Jews found this an attractive name.
So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 54, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
Reconstructed by CPJas the father’s name based on the fact that the five first persons in this list all have the same name as their fathers, see Introduction 2.1. and above, n. 2
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
This is obviously the intended name. On the interchange between ε and η and between ει and ι see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
Buried in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.5.7.
So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 159, and Introduction 2.2.1.
So in the papyrus. The declension is unusual (perhaps an abbreviation), see Introduction 2.3.1.

Described in the text as follows: Κατὰ δὲ τοῦτον ἔτυξε τὸν καιρὸν μόνον τοὺς ἐν ̔Ιεροσολύμοις καὶ τῇ χώρᾳ ̓Ιουδαίους ε̓πραγεῖν, ἀλλὰ καὶ τοὺς ἐν ̓Αλεξανδρείᾳ … Κλεοπάτρα γὰρ ἡ βασίλισσα … κατέστησεν ἡγεμόνας Χελκίαν καὶ ̓Ανανίαν, υἱοὺς ὄντας ̓Ονίου τοῦ οἰκοδομήσαντος τὸν ναὸν ἐν τῷ ̔Ηλιοπολίτῃ νομῷ … (At this time not only were the Jews in Jerusalem and in the country in a flourishing condition, but also those of Alexandria … For Queen Cleopatra … appointed as her generals Chelkias and Ananias sons of Honi who had built the temple in the nome of Heliopolis), see Introduction 6.1.1.1. On this Honi see under Honi (3) (S-H/M) in vol. 1, p. 377.

He is mentioned as a general during the struggle between Cleopatra III and her son Ptolemy Lathyrus. These are the dates of this struggle, see R. Marcus translation of Josephus in the Loeb Classical Library, vol. 7, p. 371, n. f.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
See above, n. 2. There is an obvious letter interchange in this version between χ and κ, see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3 and 2.8.3.
Described with his family members in the papyrus as οἱ τρῖς ̓Ιουδαῖοι (all three Jews) Πέρσαι τῆς ἐπιγονῆς (Persians of the epigone), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The inscription was acquired in Cairo, but its provenance is unknown.

Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6. Because of the two letters following this name (στ), which have been reconstructed as στ[ρατεγου] it has been suggested that this Helkiah be identified with Helkiah (1), but see JIGRE, 129.
So is this name recorded in Pseudo-Philo, e.g. 1:22.
The inscription was considered Jewish because of the seemingly biblical name, but see Introduction 6.6.3.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

Reading this as a variation of the biblical name Enoch was suggested by the editors, but this transliteration is unknown elsewhere. On the interchange of ο with ω and of χ with κ see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but he is late, and so may also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 60, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.5.
It has been suggested by Fikhman, SCI 15 (1996) 226, that this papyrus is associated with Jews. I assume he means those with biblical names, but see Introduction 6.6.7.
These are the dates of the emperor Heraclius mentioned in the papyrus.
Mentioned in rabbinic literature, see Introduction 6.7. Served as a high-priest in the Jewish Temple in Jerusalem.
See vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1, pp. 48-9. This person is recorded under Hanamel (1) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 98, but not included in the statistics.

Annas is how the Vulgate transliterates the name of the high-priest who persecuted Jesus – ̔́Αννας in Greek, but obviously a transliteration of the Hebrew חנן, see under Hanan (1) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 99 – see Introduction 2.2.2. The declension is unusual, see Introduction 2.2.2.1.
Described in the text as one of the “maioribus Iudaeorum” (leaders of the Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.

Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6. The initial editor of the text suggested that he be identified with Hanan (1) (B/M) in vol. 1, but see A. Momigiliano, “The New Letter by ‘Anna’ to ‘Seneca’ (Ms. 17 Erzbischöfliche Bibliothek in Köln),” Athenaeum 63 (1985) 217-9, who argues that this is the name of the 4th century Jew who wrote this treatise.
For a convincing argument that this is the provenance of this document, see Rutgers, Jews in Late Ancient Rome, 253-6.
This is the date suggested by the original editor, see also above, n. 7.
Appears in rabbinic literature, within a list of rabbinic authorities, see Introduction 6.7.
See vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1, pp. 48-9. This person is recorded under Hanan (16) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 99, but not included in the statistics.
The time of this tanna is contested. According to bKet 105a he was active before 70 CE. According to bSan17b he was a contemporary of ר' עקיבא (first two decades of the second century).
This form is recorded in Palestine, see under Hanan (21) (B/M) in vol. 1, pp. 99 and p. 102, n. 52.

His slave paid the Jewish tax, so she was Jewish, but he need not have been, see Introduction 6.1.5.1. However, his name (if correctly restored) adds to the likelihood that he was, see Introduction 6.6.
Josephus records this name as ̓́Ανανος, see e.g. AJ18:26. For the unusual declension see Introduction 2.2.1.1.7.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
The form ̔́Ανις is recorded in Palestine, see under Hanan (19) (B/M) in vol. 1, pp. 99-102 and n. 19. On the interchange of double and single ν, see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
This is the form the name takes in the NT, see under Hanan (1) (B/M) in vol. 1, pp. 99 and p. 100, n. 3.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 17, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Described in the papyri as ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.5.
The vast majority of persons in this family have biblical names, which suggest a Jewish family, but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
Jewishness indicated by name (see Introduction 6.6) and by other tombs in this burial cave which are accompanied by menorot (see Introduction 6.3.1).
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
So is the name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 17, and Introduction 2.2.1.

Described in the text as follows: Κατὰ δὲ τοῦτον ἒτυξε τὸν καιρὸν μόνον τοὺς ἐν ̔Ιεροσολύμοις καὶ τῇ χώρᾳ ̓Ιουδαίους ε̓πραγεῖν, ἀλλὰ καὶ τοὺς ἐν ̓Αλεξανδρείᾳ … Κλεοπάτρα γὰρ ἡ βασίλισσα … κατέστησεν ἡγεμόνας Χελκίαν καὶ ̓Ανανίαν, υἱοὺς ὂντας ̓Ονίου τοῦ οἰκοδομήσαντος τὸν ναὸν ἐν τῷ ̔Ηλιοπολίτῃ νομῷ … (At this time not only were the Jews in Jerusalem and in the country in a flourishing condition, but also those of Alexandria … For Queen Cleopatra … appointed as her generals Chelkias and Ananias sons of Honi who had built the temple in the nome of Heliopolis), see Introduction 6.1.1.1. On this Honi see under Honi (3) (S-H/M) in vol. 1, p. 377.

He is mentioned as a general during the struggle between Cleopatra III and her son Ptolemy Lathyrus. These are the dates of this struggle, see R. Marcus translation of Josephus in the Loeb Classical Library, vol. 7, p. 371, n. f.
So in yShab 16:2, 15c. This is one of the popular variations of the name in amoraic literature, see Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 257, and Hyman,Toldoth, 472-76.

Both versions are suggested in bBQ 114b. Obviously, his exact name was unknown to the Babylonian editors. On the first form see under Ahi (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 61, n. 1, and for the second see under Hana (H-S/M) in vol. 1.
So in bKet27b, see under Hanan (B/M).
Appears in rabbinic literature associated with the rabbis, see Introduction 6.7, and has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.6.
2nd generation amora. These are the dates.

The transliteration of ח with χ is not regular but does occur, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.2.8, p. 19. The name intended here is probably חנון, the biblical name of the (non Jewish) king of the Ammonites at the time of David, see e.g. 2 Sam 10:1.
Jewishness is suggested based on the name, see Introduction 6.6. However, for the orthography is unorthodox, see above, n. 11.
The editor writes “probably reign of Philadelphos.” These are his dates.
Described in the papyrus as ̓Ιουδαῖος τῆς ἐπιγονῆς (Jew of the epigone), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
̓Ανινᾶ is the Greek transliteration of the form חנינא, see under Hananiah (16) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 103 and p. 106, n. 41. On the additional ι see Introduction 2.2.1.1.2.
His slave paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1,and he has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.6.

Jewishness suggested based on the fact that further down in this incomplete document a Jewish tax (̓Ιουδαεικοῦ κ) is mentioned. Perhaps he paid it, see Introduction 6.1.5.1. His name may also be biblical but he is late and may be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.

Usually ̓Ανιάνιος would be understood as a variation of the Latin name Annianus (L/M). However, this is not a likely explanation for a third century BCE name from Egypt. Therefore it makes sense to interpret it as a variation of this biblical name, particularly when found in a document which includes many other biblical names.
If this is indeed his name (and not the Latin Annianus, for which it may be slightly too early) then see above, n. 18.
See above, n. 2. On this declension see Introduction 2.2.1.1.7.
So according to Mishor. Cowley,JEA 2 (1915) 210, read אניכה. This form indicates the decline of the gutturals, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.1, pp. 28-9.
The papyrus is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4. The title also adds to the identification, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.1.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
Jewishness is indicated by the combination of father-and-son’s names, see Introduction 6.6.
See above, n. 2. On the interchange of α and ο see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
See above, n. 18. It is, however, not absolutely clear what this name is. IJO 2, regarded it as non-Jewish, see p. 336, n. 5.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2, and includes the Hebrew formulae אמן סלה, see Introduction 6.2.5. It may be a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.4.1.1.
So is the name also recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 17, and Introduction 2.2.1.
See above, n. 18. The inscription may also be mentioning his title – ἂρχοντ(ος) (see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3) and his son’s title – ἀρχι(συναγώγου) (see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.1).
See above, n. 18. However, IJOsuggested that this need not be a name at all.

See above, n. 18. The reading is not quite clear ̓Ανάνιας (in which case he is probably Jewish) or ̓Ανάνιος (in which case he may not be). There is nothing else Jewish in the inscription and it is very old. Jewishness is supported by the antiquity of the inscription (when the name was typically Jewish). But antiquity is also a problem because of the presence of Jews so early on the Greek island of Ios.
The editor dated the inscription to the Hellenistic era.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
Because probably the Semitic name is intended here (see above, n. 1), there is no standard Greek transliteration for it, nor for its vocalization.
Jewishness suggested based on the name, but see Introduction 6.6.1, and above, n. 1.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but he is late, and so may also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
Jewishness suggested based on name and name of father, and other Jews in the document, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The editor dated the ostracon to the Ptolemaic period.
For the translation of 2 Macc 12:17 the Vulgate has Tubianie, i.e. the Jews of Tubias, see Introduction 2.2.2. Probably the same name is intended here.
So is this name recorded in the Apocrypha, see H & R Suppl. 151.
Jewishness of inscription indicated by the menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1, and the Hebrew words – שלום שלום שלום, see Introduction 6.2.2.

state.note: Epheboi inscription, Cyrene, Oliverio & Pugliese Carratelli

person.note: For the Bar prefix see Introduction 2.2.1.1.5. See also above, n. 2. On the interchange of θ and τ see Introduction 2.2.1.1.8.
This person could be Jewish, because of his name, see Introduction 6.6, but this is a pagan epheboi list, see Introduction 6.6.5.

state.note: Epheboi inscription, Cyrene, Oliverio & Pugliese Carratelli

person.note: See above, n. 12. The additional ρ is obviously a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.1.

state.note: Epheboi inscription, Cyrene, Oliverio & Pugliese Carratelli

person.note: For the Bar prefix see Introduction 2.2.1.1.5. See also above, n. 2.

state.note: Epheboi inscription, Cyrene, Oliverio & Pugliese Carratelli

person.note: This tomb is occupied by a family whose names are repeated over the generations. A genealogical reconstruction may suggest that the patriarch of the tomb was Judah (78), see Introduction 6.5.5.
See Introduction 2.1. The form Τωβιά is recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 151, and Introduction 2.2.1.

J. K. Rigsby., “Book Reviews” in American Journal of Philology117 (1880), 168, assumes that the name is Jewish and could be completed to Τω[βίου] “although there is ‘scarcely space’ and however unlikely it is for a ‘Jew from Parthian Dura’ to settle in Hermus,” and see also above, n. 2.
On this form see under Caleb (3) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 182, n. 9.

The various interpreters of this text suggest that ארמייא refers either to Romans, or to Syrian Christians or to pagans in general, see M. Mishor, “A New Edition of a Hebrew Letter: Oxford Ms. Heb.d.69 (P),” Lĕšonénu53 (1989) 222 (Hebrew). Some suggest, it means literally, “Aramean dog.” Thus it is not necessarily a name, and see Introduction 6.6.3.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. However, this is a list of names, none of them strictly Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.1 and 6.6.9.2.

If this is indeed this biblical name, it is unusual. On this sort of declension see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.5, pp. 22-3. However, it is doubtful if this is the intended name, since it was never used by Jews, and see Introduction 6.6.3.
The editors considered some names in this list as Jewish, but they are all Semitic rather than biblical, see Introduction 6.6.2, and also 6.6.3.
The editor thought it should be read [ד]לוי. For this name see under Daloi (S-H/M), n. 1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. Biblical names in this document add to the assessment that he is Jewish.
This form is not recorded elsewhere, but for Λεουι see under Levi (21) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 183.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
On the letter replacement between כ and י see Introduction 2.8.3.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1.
So in bKet60a. In the Tosefta he appears as מנחם.
In Hebrew – איש גליה. The assumption here is that גליה means Gaul or Galatia. On the use of this word in that sense, see A. Neubauer, La Géographie du Talmud (Paris 1868) 317.
1. Appears in rabbinic literature, see Introduction 6.7; and 2. bears the title “rabbi,” see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4.
Read by Ada Yardeni. On this sort of abbreviation see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.1, pp. 23-4.
The papyrus is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
It was assumed that this is the biblical name מנחם, even though it fits no known transliteration, because it also fits no other known name.
CIJconsidered him “sans acun doute un Juif,” perhaps because of the name, but see Introduction 6.6.3. However, he thought the entire inscription pagan, and see above, n. 8.
The inscription is in Latin and is similar to other inscriptions from Rome, but is found in the archaeological museum in Vienna. Its provenance is unknown.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.3.

IJO 1, 329, considered Hebrew inscriptions from the region as medieval, although he wrote “It is impossible to date Hebrew writings in an area where there are so few examples, and none with any internal dating.” One may assume he considered them all medieval based on the transitional pattern in all Europe, where in the Middle Ages Jews preferred to use Hebrew rather than the local scripts in their inscriptions.

Both Josephus (e.g. AJ 2:92) and LXX (H & R Suppl. 106) record this name with a double σ, probably recording the Hebrew ש, but LXX also records the form Μανασεή. On the fluidity of double and single consonants see 2.2.1.1.3.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.

person.bibl: Sirat,PCHTE, Pl. 74 (Ms. heb. C 58 [P] frag. d)
person.note: Read by Ada Yardeni. For this orthography see Introduction 2.2.3.
Jewishness indicated by Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
Jewishness indicated by the Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.
The Hebrew has led scholars to consider this inscription late, see Introduction 6.2.3.
The name מרדכי is transliterated in in LXX as Μαρδοχαῖος, see H & R Suppl. 107, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.6.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 115-6, and Introduction 2.2.1.

He is described in the text as τις ̓Ιουδαῖος̔πεκρίνατο είναι Μωϋσῆς (a certain Jew designated/ pretending to be Moses). Such a description may suggest that Moses was not his name. This is further supported by the designation ψευδο-Μωϋσῆν (Pseudo-Moses) that follows.
The event is described as Περὶ δὲ τὸν χρόνον τοῦτον … ἐν Κρήτη (at this time … in Crete).
So the event is dated in this composition.
This form fits no known transliteration of the name, but was assumed by the editors to be this one. It also does not fit any other name.
Jewishness suggested based on son’s name, but because he is late, he may also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
Jewishness may be suggested based on name but it is reconstructed, and see above, n. 1. Also in 363 CE he could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
So is this name also recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 115, and Introduction 2.2.1.
Wessley dates the papyrus to the 8th century. On the back one can see Arabic writing. This is probably why it was not included in CPJ, but the Arabic could be indication of secondary use.
So is this name also recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 114, and Introduction 2.2.1.
The vast majority of persons in this family have biblical names, which may suggest a Jewish family, but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
The first form is found in CIJ 713. The second one in CIJ 714, according to Frey. IJO 1, App11, did not read it. See also Introduction 2.1, and above, n. 2.
If this is the right reconstruction of the name, this could be the tomb of the daughter of the person buried under CIJ 713, but both reconstructions are tentative.
Jewishness is indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
See Introduction 2.1. If the emendation is correct, the suffix is obviously a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.5.
Described in the text as ̔Εβρεος (Hebrew), see Introduction 6.1.2.
The editor dated the inscription to the Byzantine period.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.

IJO 1, 330, wrote of the Hebrew inscriptions from the region “The dating given by Chwolson has no real basis, and the inscriptions are probably medieval.” One may assume he considered them all medieval based on the transitional pattern in all Europe, where in the Middle Ages Jews preferred to use Hebrew rather than the local scripts in their inscriptions, see Introduction 6.2.3.
The inscription is very fragmentary and its exact purpose remains unclear.

Jewishness depends on the editor’s interpretation of this name as Jewish (but see above, n. 1), since the title – ἂρχω[ν], cannot serve as indicator of Jewishness, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3. IJO considered it non-Jewish.
See Introduction 2.1. This form is unknown from any transliteration, but was so interpreted by the editor, see next note.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1. The editor concedes he could also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
This form is unknown from any transliteration, but was so interpreted by the editor, perhaps because the person on the inscription is identified as a Jew.
Described in the text as “Iude[i]s” (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.4. However, the inscription is accompanied by the Christian symbol chi rho, see Kraemer, HTR 84 (1991) 160-1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

state.note: Altar with male and female bust, Suwarek

person.note: See Introduction 2.1, and above, n. 2. However, the name is a reconstruction of the editor.

Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1. The pagan character of this altar militates against this identification, see Introduction 6.10.2. IJO 2 did not include it in its corpus, see p. 490, n. 30.

state.note: Aurelius (97), Carpus (1)’s son, Philtate (1)’s husband, Artemia (3)’s brother, Victoria (4)’s father

person.note: See Introduction 2.1, and above, n. 2. However, the name is a reconstruction of the editor.
The editor suggested this reading, but most of the name in the inscription is missing and see IJO2, p. 455, n. 27, and above, n. 1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This form does not fit any known transliteration of the name, but is also like no other name.
Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The inscription may still date to the Persian period.
This form is recorded in Palestine, see under Mattathias (28; 37; 39; 47) (B/M) in vol. 1, pp. 192-3.
The text is Greek but the subscription is in Coptic script, see Introduction 2.9. This is obviously the same transliteration.

Some persons in this papyrus have biblical names, which suggested to the editor that “The whole nomenclature betrays persons of Jewish extraction,” but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7. The Coptic subscription particularly suggests this.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
This is obviously a variation on the same name, see above, n. 2.
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
See above, n. 2. On the interchange of θ and τ see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above n. 1.
See above, n. 13. On the formula διακοσύ[νην] τοῦ Θεοῦ (God’s justice), see Introduction 6.10.1.2.
Because the name Aurelius appears in the inscription, the editors dated it to after the bestowal of Roman citizenship in 212 by Caracalla, see Introduction 1.3.1.
See above, n. 13. See MAMA 9, p. 137, for the suggestion that it is an Anatolian name. IJO 2 did not include it in its corpus, see p. 345, n. 10.
See above, n. 20. IJO 2 did not include it in its corpus, see p. 386, n. 123.

person.bibl: Drew-Bear et al.,Phrygian Votive Steles, no. 413
person.note: The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
This is the form of this name in the NT, see under Mattathias (16) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 191. The declension is unusual (perhaps an abbreviation), see Introduction 2.3.1.
See above, n. 22. The inscription seems to be in dedication of Zeus, see Introduction 6.10.2.
See above, n. 8. On the interchange of θ and τ see Introduction 2.2.1.1.3.
Jewishness suggested based on 1. the possible Semitic בר (son) element in the father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.2.1; and 2. the name, but see above, n. 1.
The editor dated the plate to the Hellenistic period.

Although usually the name Shabtai in itself does not indicate Jewishness, see Introduction 6.6.6, in this document something else is happening. This document is a list of names, 30% being biblical (see Introduction 6.6.9.2). The concentration of biblical names in this document is unusual. They are Joseph (3 persons), Jacob (8 persons) and Isaac (11 persons). It seems that since this neighborhood was densely populated by Jews with unoriginal names, the name Shabtai (used by 7 persons) was probably also used by Jews. Thus I consider these 7 persons as Jews.
