The inscription is bilingual. So in the Latin. The Hebrew has שמואל. The Latin form probably knows the version of this name in the Vulgate (Samuhel) but not very precisely.
See above, n. 48 The inscription includes reference to the “licem quem Dominus dedit Iudeis” (the law which the Lord gave to the Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.6.
The inscription is dated “Merobaudes iterum et Satornino consulibus” (when Merobaudes for the second time and Saturnius were consuls). This is their consular year.
Scholars hold the Hebrew as a reason for considering this inscription medieval, see Introduction 6.2.3.
See Introduction 2.1. In Josephus this name is recorded as Σαμούηλος (e.g. AJ 5:340) see Introduction 2.2.1.
Jewishness of the inscription indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
On this sort of abbreviation see Introduction 2.2.1.1.6.
Described in the text as Εἰουδέων (of the Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.3. See also above, n. 57.
In Greek –̔Ραββί … ἀρχσ[υνάγωγος Φ]ρύγιος. On this person and the reason for the provenance of his inscription in Jerusalem, and his possible identification with Samuel (2) see above, n. 5.

The biblical name (see Introduction 6.6), the titles rabbi (see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4), and archisynagogus (see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.1), the Jewish characters – למישכבך that accompany the inscription (see Introduction 6.2.2), and its provenance from Jerusalem (see Introduction 6.8), all indicate Jewishness.
The inscription was acquired in Alexandria, but its provenance is unknown.
The editor compared the inscription to CIJ 964 (from Ashkelon), dated to 604 CE.

The inscription was considered Jewish 1. because of the name, but itcould also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7; and 2. because of title, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3. The tomb also contains a curse formula, but see Introduction 6.10.1.3.CIJconsiders it more Christian than Jewish.

state.note: Graffito on lead tablet, Santa Maria, Majorca, Millás

person.note: This is obviously an abbreviation, see Introduction 2.3.1. The interpretation of this abbreviation as referring to this name belongs to the editor.
On the Don River, near its junction with the Sea of Azov.
Jewishness suggested based on name reconstruction, see Introduction 6.6, and on a symbol the editor identified as a palm-branch and Jewish, but see Introduction 6.3.2.

Its Jewish character is assumed by Williams, ZPE 92 (1992) 251, n. 23, based on onomastic grounds, see above, n. 62, but she leaves room for doubt in her interpretation. IJO 1 considered it non-Jewish, and see also Introduction 6.6.7.
In Greek – ἀρχιδ(έκανος). The word δεκαν(ίας) (quorum – מניין) is mentioned earlier in the text, see Reynolds & Tannenbaum, 28-9.
Described in the inscription as προσήλ(υτος), see Introduction 6.1.6.2.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.
In Greek – πρεσβευτὴς (appears twice) ἱερεύς Περγεούς .
This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.4.1.1.1.
Jewishness based on the conglomeration of three forms of the name Samuel together in one inscription, and its undeclined form here, favored by Jews, see Introduction 6.6, and above, n. 62.
The inscription was purchased in Alexandria, but its exact find spot is unknown.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but since the date of the inscription, as well as its purpose, are dubious, he could also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.7. It was further suggested based on title, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.2.1.
The editor dated the epitaph to the Byzantine period.

The form Σίμωνis clearly a Greek name (WGE, 1393-4). It was, however, adopted early in the Hellenistic period as the Greek equivalent of the biblical שמעון, see Introduction 1.2.3. It is true that Josephus makes the distinction and uses the form Σεμεών for the biblical son of Joseph (Schalit, NB, 110) and Σίμων (Schalit, NB, 113) for his contemporaries of this name. LXX likewise uses Συμεών for the son of Jacob (H & R Suppl. 148) while using Σίμωνfor persons mentioned in the apocrypha. However, the שמעון mentioned in Ezra 10:31 is transliterated Σίμων in LXX, indicating the fluidity of the forms, and see further under Simon (B/M) in vol. 1, pp. 226-7, n. 2, and Introduction 1.2.4.
The assumption of his Jewishness is based on his presence in Jerusalem at the time of the Pesach pilgrimage.
In Greek – Κυρηναῖον. This person is recorded under Simon (39) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 219, but not included in the statistics.
This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them.
Described in the text as one of several Jews who had διάλεξις γέγονεν (conducted a dispute) with Christians.
Although not specifically described as Jewish, he is portrayed in this text as disputing doctrine with the Pope Silvester, as do others who are expressly described as Jews.
So is this name recorded in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 148, and Introduction 2.2.1.
This text is a disputation between Jews and Christians. In 1:7 we learn that it took place ἐν Καραθαγέννῃ (in Carthage).
His father is a professed Jew who wrote this treatise and converted, see Introduction 6.1.6.3.
On the dating of this text see Dan, Zion 36 (1971) 1-26.
This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them, this time in Latin.
Described in the title of this disputation as “Iudaei” (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.

Provenance unknown, western Diaspora assumed, based on the fact that the author (a certain monk by the name of Eugerius) wrote in Latin, see A. Harnack, Texte und Untersuchungen zur Geschichte der altchristlichen Literatur 1 (Leipzig 1883) 3.
See A. B. Hulen, “The ‘Dialogues with the Jews’ as Sources for the Early Jewish Argument against Christianity,” JBL 51 (1932) 62, n. 6.
This is where this martyrdom story takes place.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαῖος τις (a certain Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
The editor dated the text to “Aurelian” times. These are his dates of his reign.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
Intended to be לשמעון (for Simon). For the interchange of letters see Introduction 2.8.3.
The document is in Jewish characters. However, this is a list of names, none of them strictly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is an account mentioning two persons with biblical names, and hence Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The man’s son is described as ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.4.
The papyrus is dated to these years.

This papyrus is a list of names. None of them specifically biblical, and only identified as such because the editors thought they were commonly used by Jews, see CPJ1, pp. 176-7, but this is not likely, see above, n. 1.

Jewishness suggested by CPJ 1, p. 196,based on his identification with Simon (23), but there is no proof thereof, and if they are not identical, he is probably not Jewish, because his name is not enough see above, n. 1
The ostraca are dated to these years.
Jewishness suggested based on name and name of father, but both are problematic, see above, n. 1, and Introduction 6.6.1.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1, and Introduction 6.6.4.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The ostraca are dated to these two years.
This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them.
The ostracon is dated to either of these years.
See above, n. 54. However, his proximity to a Joseph makes this much more likely, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
Jewishness suggested because another Jew (Joseph [12]) is mentioned on this ostracon, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
This is an abbreviation, see Introduction 2.3.1.
This ostracon consists of a list of names. One of them (Joshua [3]) is Jewish so the editors considered them all so, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
This is a literary text. In it he is described in Greek – πρέσβεις ̓Ιουδαίων (elder of the Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
This is a debate before the emperor Trajan. It must be dated to before the destruction of Egyptian Jewry, and his death.
His son paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
His daughter paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
The declension is probably a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.5. What the first three letters are doing in this name is unclear. Perhaps they are some sort of Egyptian prefix.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
His son paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
See above, n. 81. On the double consonant see Introduction 2.3.3.4.
Jewishness suggested based on his presence on an ostracon with biblical names from the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them. It looks feminine, see under Simon (F/G).
Described in the papyrus as ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.5.
This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them.
Mentioned in a list which includes many biblical names but is of a late date, see Introduction 6.6.7.
Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
Jewishness indicated by son’s designation – ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.4.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to persons with biblical names mentioned in the same document, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The editor dated the ostracon to the Ptolemaic period.
This papyrus is a list of mostly biblical names, and thus probably of Jews, but this one is not, see above, n. 1, and Introduction 6.6.9.2.
He and his partner are described in this papyrus as ̓Ιουδαῖοι (Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.

It has been suggested by Clarysse, “Jews in Trikomia,” 202, that he was a Jew, perhaps because of the name, and certainly because of the make-up of the village population. However, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.

The person he has dealings with is described as a Σαμαρίτῃ (Samaritan), see Introduction 6.1.6.4. The orthography of his name may suggest a Samaritan or Jew, but the late date of the document makes this unnecessary, see Introduction 6.6.7.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to persons with biblical names mentioned in the same document, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
See Introduction 2.1. This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them. It looks feminine, and see above, n. 125.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them, in Latin.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name (but see Introduction 6.6.7) and his title – rebbi, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4.
Some of the formulae in the inscription have led scholars to consider it late, although it is in Latin rather than Hebrew, as most medieval Jewish inscriptions from Spain are, see Introduction 6.2.3.
This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them.
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them.
It is not clear whether Αβα is a name or a title, see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.1, p. 33.
His son, Τανοῦμ, buried in Jaffa, is no longer considered of Egyptian origin, and is recorded in vol. 2 under Tanhum (S-H/M).
Found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.5.7.
Parembole, where his son was centurion, is a village in Egypt.
This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them.
See above, n. 159. The inscription is bilingual (Hebrew and Latin) see Introduction 6.2.2.
The inscription is dated = ind(ictione) XV, con(sulatu) Valeri.
The original editors suggest he may be Jewish because of the name, but see above, n. 1. IJO 1 considered the inscription non-Jewish.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.
See Introduction 2.1. This name has many non-standard transliterations. This is one of them.
This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.4.1.1.1.

See above, n. 135. The inscription mentions the name twice, once as Sarah (24)’s father and once as somebody else’s father (whose name is not preserved). I assume it is the tombstone of two of this man’s children, and that he is the same person.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1, and Introduction 6.5.5.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1, and Introduction 6.5.5.

See above, n. 54. Jewishness also suggested based on the unique function of “representative” (πρεσβευτῶν) of this person in Italy, perhaps indicating his relation to the Jewish community in Ptolemais, Cyrenaica, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to Jewish tombs, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
This is a Jewish politeuma inscription, see Introduction 6.4.2.2.
The date is reconstructed by the editors.
Jewishness could be suggested based on the name, but for the non-Jewish character of the name שמעון in Palmyra see Stark, PNPI, 115, and vol. 2, under Simon (B/M).

state.note: Sarah (32) and Alexander (60)’s father, of Ptolemais

person.note: In Greek – Πτυλεμαική, in Aramaic – קרנית.
I assume the two ossuaries mention the same person, because they were both found in the same tomb, and they each belong to another child of this person.
The name was found on a Jewish ossuary in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.5.6.

This burial cave was identified as housing Jews from Cyrenaica, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1.1, p. 49. This person is recorded under Simon (116) (B/M) in vol. 1, p. 222, but not included in the statistics.
See above, n. 10. The editor also suggested reading Εὔμεον.

Jewishness suggested based on name (and orthography, see above, n. 10), but see also above, n. 1. Because there is no date he could also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7, and this may not be the correct reading, see previous note.
The seal is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
The Hebrew transcription is so bad one should consult the original publication – Cross, Leaves, 154.
This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.4.1.1.1, and it is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This is the suggested reading of CPJ, see Introduction 2.1, and below, n. 5.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.3.

See Introduction 2.1. Both in LXX (H & R Suppl. 137) and in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 106) the judge by this name is transliterated as Σαμψών. The combination Σαμψ leads one to assume that this is the name intended, even if the suffix is different.
This family is described in the text as Σαμαρῖται (Samaritans), see Introduction 6.1.6.4.
This transliteration fits no known form, but perhaps this name is intended.
This ostracon describes a feast presided over by a Jewish priest (Joseph [13]). Since it makes sense that this is a Jewish feast, I considered all participants Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.
Jewishness suggested based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.3.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
Because it is probably the Semitic name intended here (see above, n. 1), there is no standard Greek transliteration for it, nor for its vocalization.
This ostracon describes a feast presided over by a Jewish priest (Joseph [13]). Since it makes sense that this is a Jewish feast, I considered all participants Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

div.note: Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 9:1.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 8:2.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 22:20. אביתר was a priest under King David.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 14:50. אבנר was King Saul’s general.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:5. אברהם is the name of the biblical patriarch, forefather of the Jewish people. The name was not in use by Jews in Palestine in late antiquity, see vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1.1, p. 5. It had a different fate in the Diaspora, particularly in Egypt, see Cohen, JSJ 7 (1976) and Honigman, ZPE 146 (2004). See also Mussies, “Jewish Personal Names,” 250. These studies suggest that the name was used in Egypt by Jews. However, for doubts about the Jewishness of this name see Bohak, “Good Jews, Bad Jews.” In this corpus, the name is used as an indicator of Jewishness.

Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 3:3. אבשלום was David’s rebellious son. As shown in vol. 1, pp. 60-1, the name was used by Jews in Palestine in post-biblical times. However, the name was also a Semitic name, used by non-Jews, see e.g. Negev, Qedem 32, 10; Harding, ICPIANI, 12.
Biblical, see 1 Sam 15:8. אגג is the name of the king of Amalek.
Biblical, e.g. Ex 4:14. אהרון was the name of Moses’ brother, the first priest. As shown in vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1.1, pp. 5-6, the name was not used by Jews in post-biblical Palestine.
Biblical, e.g. Ex 31:2.

Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 6:3. S. Mandelkern, veteris Testamenti Concordantiae Hebraicae atque Chaldaicae (Jerusalem 1969) 1358-9, claims this is a name, probably short for אחיהו, also recorded in the Bible, but in all the examples he brings it could also mean “his brother(s).”
Biblical, e.g. Job 1:1. איוב was the man who gave the biblical book its name.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:14.
Biblical, e.g. Num 16:1.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 17:1. אליהו was the name of a prophet.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:22. This is a Second Temple name, since it is mentioned for more than one person, but only in Second Temple compositions (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr).
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 19:16. אלישע was a prophet, and Elijah’s disciple.
Biblical, e.g. Ex 6:23. Further on this name see vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1.2, pp. 6-7 and 65-79.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 19:2.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:41.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:11. The name is probably Aramaic, since it is only documented in post-exilic books of the Bible (Ezra, Neh). See also Lipiński, Studies 1, 111.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 11:22. בניה is one of King David’s generals.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 35:18. בנימין is Jacob’s youngest son and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 32:12. ברוך was Jeremiah’s scribe.
Biblical, e.g. Zach 1:1.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 40:5. גדליה was the prefect the Babylonians nominated after they conquered Jerusalem and deposed the Davidian kings.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 3:15.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 21:8. דואג was David’s Idumean enemy.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 16:13. דוד was the name of the famous king of Israel.
Biblical priestly course, see 1 Chr 24:18.
Biblical, e.g. Dan 1:7. דניאל is the biblical figure who gave his name to the book of Daniel.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 42:1.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 12:13.

Biblical, Josh 7:1. This is a Second Temple name. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews. Various forms of the name are recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 85-6; and in Idumea, see AOFCI, 99.
Biblical, see e.g. Neh 11:14.

Biblical, 1 Chr 8:17. This is a Second Temple name. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews. Various forms of the name are recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 85-6; and in Idumea, see AOFCI, 99.

Biblical, Ezra 10:43. This is a Second Temple name. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews. Various forms of the name are recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 374-7, and Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 294.
Biblical, e.g. Num 13:4.
Biblical, e.g. Zech 1:1. זכריה is the prophet who gave the name to the biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Haggai 1:12. חגי was the post-exilic prophet who gave the name to a biblical book. Further on this name in the Diaspora see Williams, JSJ 36 (2005).
Biblical, e.g. Num 13:5.
Biblical, e.g. Ex 17:10.
Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr 24:15. This is a strange name for Jews, because חזיר means pig. Yet names with the element חזיר (=חזירא, חזירו) are recorded in Idumea, see AOFCI, nos. 88, 174, 182.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:1. חזקיה was king of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:37.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 5:35. חם was one of Noah’s sons.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 5:23. חנוך is the name of the almost mythical forefather of Noah who is supposed to have never died. On Enochic literature in the Second Temple period, see J. Greenfield, “Prolegomena,” in H. Odeberg [ed.], 3 Enoch or the Hebrew Book of Enoch [New York 1973] xvi-xxiii.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 32:7.

Biblical, e.g. Jer 35:4. This name has such an independent standing that one often loses sight of the fact that it is probably an abbreviation of חנניה. Because this distinction is already biblical, I have not listed the two names under a single heading here.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 28:1.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 3:11.

Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10. The most famous Τωβίας of Second Temple times are the heroes of the apocryphal book Tobit and his father, Τωβίθ. Whether these forms include the Hebrew theophoric element – יה is unclear. Semitic names of this root where quite common, see e.g. Harding, ICPIANI,386.
Biblical, e.g. Num 13:6. כלב was one of the spies Moses sent to inspect Canaan.
Biblical, Ezra 10:30.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 11:27. לוט was Abraham’s nephew.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:34. לוי was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel. A relevant question is whether all persons named Levi in this period were Levites. On this see Stern, “Aspects of Jewish Society,” 599.
Biblical, e.g. Mi 1:1. מיכה is the biblical prophet who gave his name to a book.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 21:1.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:14. מנחם was the one before last king of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 41:51. מנשה is Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Esth 2:1. מרדכי was Queen Esther’s uncle.

Biblical, e.g. Ex 2:10. משה was the famous lawgiver. Unlike in Palestine (see vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1.1, pp. 5 and 190), in the Diaspora the biblical name of Moses was sometimes used, but many time scholars identified similar looking names as Moses (see both Derda, ZPE115 [1997] and Williams, ZPE 118 [1997]) and then as Jews, but this is a circular argument.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 22:3.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 38:1.

Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:43. This name is only documented in post-exilic biblical books (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). In Palestine this was a very popular Hasmonean name (see vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1.2, pp. 6-7 and 191-6) but in the Diaspora it was not, and in Asia Minor variations of this name were used because they were Anatolian, see Introduction 6.6.4.1. Because of this, inscriptions from Asia Minor, identified as Jewish because of the name, are here considered doubtful.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 5:29. נח went into the ark during the deluge.
Biblical, e.g. Nah 1:1. נחום was the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 11:22. נחור was Abraham’s father.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 1:1. נחמיה was the Jewish leader who gave his name to a historical biblical book.

Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 7:2. נתן was the name of David’s prophet. Because this is such an independent biblical name, one loses sight of the fact that it is in fact an abbreviation of a name such as יונתן or נתנאל, and is listed here under an independent heading.
Biblical, Jer 36:26.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 6:29. This name has become popular among other Semitic people, see Introduction 6.6.1. The names עבדא / עבדי are recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 102.
Biblical, e.g. Obad 1. עבדיה was the name of the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:12.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 7:1. עזרא is the scribe who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 14:21. עזריה was a king of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. Ex 6:18. עמרם was Moses’ father.
Biblical, Neh 10:27.

Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:45. Obviously, here the Bible preserves the abbreviated form of the non-biblical עקביה/עקיבא, which became popular in post-biblical times, but see also Introduction 6.6.2. As in vol. 1, pp. 203-4, I have documented all names from this Semitic root under this biblical form, because they are not recorded in the Hebrew Bible, but were popular among Jews, particularly in rabbinic society. However, they were obviously used by other Semites, see e.g. Harding, ICPIANI, 426.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:25. עשו was Jacob’s brother.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 10:23.
Biblical, e.g. Ex 6:25. פנחס was the name of Aaron’s grandson. In the Bible the name is spelled as a rule פינחס.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:32. ראובן was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 9:2. שאול was the first king of Israel.

Biblical, Ezra 2:42. This is a Second Temple name. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews. Various forms of the name are recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1093, for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 340, and for Palmyrans, see Stark, PNPI, 50.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 9:4.

Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:15. The name and its many derivatives became very popular in the Diaspora, because of its association with the Jewish Shabbat, but soon lost its unique Jewish character and, particularly in Egypt, became a common pagan and then Christian name, see CPJ vol. 3, 43-56, and Cohen, “Shabtai.” Further on this name in the Diaspora see Williams, JSJ 36 (2005). It is an unlikely indication of Jewishness despite assertions of many scholars, see Introduction 6.6.6.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:13. שלום was the name of a king of Israel, but variations of the name were also used by other Semites, see Introduction 6.6.1.

Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 12:24. שלמה was the son of David, King of Israel. However, when transcribed into Greek, it is difficult to distinguish it from the previous name, and both were popular among non-Jewish Semites, see Introduction 6.6.3.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:20. שמואל was the prophet who gave his name to two biblical books.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:33. שמעון was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel. The name Simon is not only Jewish but also Greek. It was thus very popular among Jews, see under Simon (1) (B/M) in vol. 1, pp. 26-7. However, just because a person bears this name, it is not an indication that he is Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.4.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:32.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 13:24. שמשון was the name of a Judge.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 3:4.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:15. The name is associated with a son of Ishmael – i.e. it may be of Arab extraction. The name תימא is recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 117.
